awd_titl_txt: Research Intiation Award: Long Time Behavior for Systems of Coupled Partial Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
Research Initiation Awards provide support for junior and mid-career faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities who are building new research programs or redirecting and rebuilding existing research programs. It is expected that the award helps to further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, improves research and teaching at his home institution, and involves undergraduate students in research experiences. The award to Virginia State University has potential broader impact in a number of areas. The goal of the project is to study the existence and uniqueness of solutions of systems of strongly coupled partial differential equations given an appropriate initial configuration and to study the long time behavior of the solutions. The models have wide applications in areas such as aerospace engineering, civil engineering, and environmental sciences. Undergraduate students will gain research experiences and courses in ordinary and partial differential equations will be enhanced.

The goal of the project is to study the control, optimization and stability analysis centered on physically significant systems composed of dynamical "interactive" inhomogeneous structures, whose behavior is governed by nonlinear systems of coupled partial differential equations (PDEs). The two PDE-components act on separate and adjacent media. Two specific models under consideration are: (1) Fluid-structure interaction (FSI), where the model consists of the Navier Stokes equation coupled on the interface with dynamic elasticity; and  (2) Structure acoustic interaction (SAI), in an acoustic chamber with an elastic or thermoelastic shell as a flexible wall. The SAI model consists of hybrid coupling between an acoustic wave equation and a shell equation which is possibly nonlinear. Control theoretic issues to be studied are: (a) stabilization, particularly stabilization of unstable equilibria in FSI and stabilization of SAI subject to weak dissipation; and (b) well-posedness, particularly seeking suitable feedback control such that the solution to FSI with moving interface is well-posed. Both models could be generalized to other structures where the developed mathematical technology could be applied to other coupled systems.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Overview

The major goals of the project are two folds: (1) advancing the understanding of some fundamental mathematical theoretic problems, such as long time behavior and stabilization, of coupled system of PDEs and its constituting component arising from physics, engineering and biology; (2) broadening the participation of underrepresented group in STEM.

For the first goal, the qualitative behavior of some benchmark coupled systems and its constitutive component of partial differential equations was studied. For the second goal, African American is an underrepresented group among college students seeking and obtaining a Bachelor or higher degree in STEM areas. Virginia State University (VSU), is a Historically Black Collage (HBCU) where more than 95% of the students are African American. An indispensable component of the project is the involvement of STEM major undergraduate or graduate students. Exploring the research problems in the project could prepare the participating students to pursue an advanced degree or an industrial career in STEM.

In summary, this project has two critical interacting components: research and education. By fulfilling the goals of these components in this project, the PI hopes to fulfill the goal of broadening the participation of African Americans in the STEM enterprise.

Summary of outcomes

The outcomes of this grant could be summarized as the following: (1). The project advances the study of the control theoretical problem for coupled interactive systems of PDEs, such as fluid-structure interaction where a structure is submersed in the surrounding fluid. We designed feedback mechanism to globally stabilize the solution to a non-trivial equilibrium solution when the system is subject to a time independent external force. (2). We also studied the long-time behavior of the Navier-Stokes equation, the constitutive component of FSI and many other interactive coupled systems of PDE. We investigated the pullback dynamics (existence of pullback attractor and its fractal dimension and other theoretical problems) for the NS equation when it is subject to time dependent external force and when the underlying domain is a non-smooth Liptchitz domain. This lays the foundation of studying the large time behavior of FSI when it is subject to time dependent external force. (3). We also conducted numerical simulation of FSI to investigate and visualize the effectiveness of feedback control mechanism on FSI. (4). The PI followed the project-based learning approach to incorporate control theory related projects into the senior seminar course for math majors at VSU every fall semester starting from 2017 and organized comprehensive summer research programs consecutively for the summer of 2018-2020. These activities improved students’ independent thinking and written and oral communication skills and contributed to new institutional education and research resources. The research findings resulted in several journal papers and conference presentations.

 

Intellectual merits:

Rigorous mathematical analysis of the FSI model is not widely available in the literature until recently. In particular, the stabilization results of FSI when it is subject to an external force are mostly local in nature in the literature. In contrast, the stabilization result the PI established is global and it is suited for stabilization even for potentially large initial data. In addition, the wellposedness of the NS equation is 3D is still unknown. We assume general assumption on the external force when studying the large-time behavior of NS equation when it is subject to time dependent external force: the non-autonomous external force does not have to be uniformly bounded in time; some results are in 3D, therefore, require subtle estimates that are held true only in 3D; when the underlying domain is Lipschitz-like, the lack of smoothness of the domain was overcome by constructing a background flow. Due to the pandemic, the summer program in 2020 was run fully online, which could provide useful framework to run such programs online in the future.

Broader impacts:

The interaction between fluid and structure gives rise to a rich variety of phenomena with applications in cell biology, biomedical engineering and naval and space engineering. The mathematical problems we studied answer the question how the dynamics behaves as time elapses and how to stabilize the dynamics near a possibly unstable non-trivial equilibrium, both of which are of great importance to engineering applications.

Using the fund from this grant, the PI was able to train fifteen undergraduate and graduate students in the summer or in-semester research programs. Six of these students are female and all but one is African American. Student participants received awards in various professional conferences and obtained full time jobs in some of the most high-profile companies such as Lockheed Martin and IBM and enrolled in various STEM based PhD programs, such as Computational and Applied Mathematics and Biomedical Sciences. The positive outcomes of these students could go a long way of attracting more well qualified minority students into receiving higher education in STEM and changing the underrepresentation of African Americans in the STEM workforce.
